facts.text: Writ Petition No. 110 of 1966 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of fundamental rights

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 110 of 1966. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for en- forcement of fundamental rights.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by SubbaRao, C.J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SubbaRao, C.J.

facts.text: Petition seeks declaration that Sections 32A, 32D, 32E, 32FF and 32G of the Pepsu Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, 1955 as amended by Act XV of 1956 are illegal, ultra vires and unconstitutional

anchor.surface_text: This is a petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for a declaration that the provisions of Sections 32A9 32D, 32E, 32FF and 32G of the Pepsu Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, 1955, as amended by Act XV of 1956, hereinafter called the Act, are illegal, ultra vires and unconstitutional

facts.text: Petition seeks declaration that Rule 28 of the Pepsu Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Rules, 1958 is illegal and void

anchor.surface_text: and for a declaration that the provisions of Rule 28 of the Pepsu Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Rules, 1958, hereinafter called the Rules, are illegal and void,

facts.text: Petitioner owned land measuring about 284 bighas situated in village Narinderpura

anchor.surface_text: The facts may be briefly stated The petitioner owned land measuring about 284 bighas situated in village Narinderpura.

facts.text: In the year 1956 petitioner transferred one half of the said land in favour of his wife Shrimati Charanjeet Kaur

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1956 he transferred one half of the said land in favour of his wife Shrimati Charanjeet Kaur.

facts.text: Excluding the land transferred to wife, land remaining in hands of petitioner is below ceiling prescribed under the Act

anchor.surface_text: Excluding the land so transferred, the land remaining in the hands of the petitioner is admittedly below the ceiling prescribed under the Act.

facts.text: Petitioner is in personal cultivation of his land excluding that sold to wife, which is below ceiling

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner is admittedly in personal cultivation of his land, which, excluding that sold to his wife, is below the ceiling prescribed under the Act.

facts.text: On October 30, 1956, Act XV of 1956 was passed by Legislature of Patiala and East Punjab Union amending Pepsu Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, 1955

anchor.surface_text: On October 30, 1956, Act XV of 1956 was passed by the Legislature of the Patiala and East Punjab Union. It amended the Pepsu Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, 1955.

facts.text: Act XV of 1956 added Chapter 4-A and imposed ceiling on land under personal cultivation

anchor.surface_text: By the amendment Chapter 4-A was added to the earlier Act and also a ceiling was imposed on land under personal cultivation.

facts.text: On January 14, 1959 Punjab Legislature passed Pepsu Tenancy and Agricultural Land Amendment Act, 1959 (Act III of 1959)

anchor.surface_text: On January 14,1959 the Punjab Legislature passed Pepsu Tenancy and Agricultural Land  Amendment  Act, 1959,  Act III of 1959 .

facts.text: Act III of 1959 provides that transfer or disposition of land after August 21, 1956 except to certain persons shall not affect State's right to surplus area

anchor.surface_text: Under the said amending Act, numbertransfer or other disposition of land effected after August 21, 1956, except in favour of persons mentioned thereunder, shall affect the right of the State Government under the Act to the surplus area

facts.text: Special Collector, Chandigarh served draft statement on petitioner on May 31, 1962 holding certain extent of land as surplus including land transferred to wife

anchor.surface_text: Relying upon that section and including in the total area held by the petitioner the land transferred by him in favour of his wife the Special Collector, Chandigarh, on May 31, 1962, served a draft statement on the petitioner holding that certain extent of land was surplus area.

facts.text: Petitioner filed this petition questioning the order of the Collector

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner, questioning the order of the Collector on various grounds, filed this petition for the enforcement of his fundamental rights.

facts.text: Permissible limit under Act is thirty standard acres or eighty acres if converted

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 of Pepsu Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, 1955 as amended by Act XV of 1956 provides Permissible limit for the purpose of this Act is thirty standard acres of land and where such thirty standard acres on being companyverted into ordinary acres exceed eighty acres, such eighty acres

facts.text: Petitioner's land excluding transfer would be within permissible area but including it above

anchor.surface_text: In the instant case if the transfer by the petitioner in favour of his wife is number ignored, the petitioners land would be within the permissible area. But if ignored it would be above that area.

facts.text: Compensation payable under Act is not market value but as prescribed

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly also under the provisions of the Act, companypensation payable in respect of the surplus area is number its market value but that ascertained 1 in the manner prescribed by the Act and the Rules made thereunder.

facts.text: On August 13, 1956, Pepsu Tenancy and Agricultural Second Amendment Bill, 1956 published in Pepsu Gazette Extraordinary

anchor.surface_text: It appears that on August 13, 1956, the Pepsu Tenancy and Agricultural Second Amendment Bill, 1956 was published in Pepsu Gazette Extraordinary fixing the permissible limits of a landholder

facts.text: Last Settlement in Pepsu area took place about 50 years ago

anchor.surface_text: It is said that the last Settlement, in Pepsu area took place 50 years ago that is to say, the average yield per acre fixed by the said last Settlement Report shall be substituted

facts.text: Village Narinderpura was part of Patiala State at time of last Settlement

anchor.surface_text: The village Narinderpura was part of Patiala State at that time,. The provisions of rule 28 accordingly run companytrary to the letter and spirit of the provisions of section 32G of the Act.

facts.text: Court holds Section 32FF valid

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that s. 32FF is valid and as the Ian, I acquired is admittedly above the ceiling, the second proviso to art 31A has numberapplication.

facts.text: Court holds Rule 28 not ultra vires the Act on facts presented

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that on the facts placed before us we cannot hold that the Rules are ultra vires the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The second proviso to Art. 31-A of the Constitution reads Provided that where any law makes any provision for the acquisition by the State of any estate and where any land comprised therein is held by a person under his personal cultivation, it shall not be lawful for the State to acquire any portion of such land as is within the ceiling limit applicable to him under any law for the time being in force . . . unless the law relating to the acquisition of such land provides for payment of compensation at a rate which shall not be less than the market value thereof.

concepts.interpretation: Bars challenge to estate acquisition laws under Arts.14,19,31 even if unreasonable; second proviso inapplicable as land above ceiling

arguments.claim: Legislature competent to enact retrospective laws to prevent evasion of impending statutes

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed that the Parliament can make an Act in respect of the matters within its purview either prospectively or retrospectively. It is a well known legislative device to put an earlier date in order to prevent the evasion of an impending statute.

arguments.claim: s.32FF valid to frustrate transfers anticipating ceiling law; ignores transfers after 21 Aug 1956 to relations for surplus calculation but valid between parties

anchor.surface_text: Section 32FF was added to frustrate such devices and to make the enforcement of the Act really effective. Under the said section such a transfer made after August 21, 1956, shall not affect the rights of the State Government under the Act to the surplus area

arguments.claim: Art. 31A bars challenge to acquisition of estates even if unreasonable restriction under Art.19(2)

anchor.surface_text: The validity of such a provision may perhaps be questioned under certain circumstances on the ground that it is an unreasonable restriction within the meaning of Art. 19(2) of the Constitution. But that is not open to the petitioner as the amending Act giving retrospective operation relates to an estate. Therefore, Art. 31A operates as a bar

arguments.claim: No delegation/abdication in s.32FF r.23A as policy for relations (benami prevention) laid down and workable

anchor.surface_text: From the mere fact that the enumeration of the relations is left to the State Government, we cannot say that the Legislature has abdicated its function. It has clearly laid down the policy and on the basis of that policy enumeration of the relations can easily be worked out.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislature competent to enact retrospective law to prevent evasion of impending ceiling legislation by transfers to relatives; such transfers ignored only for determining surplus area against State; acquisition relates to estate protected by Art. 31A barring challenge under Arts. 14, 19, 31; land exceeds ceiling limit

holdings.text: provisions of s. 32FF read with r. 23A do not amount to delegation of legislative power or abdication

anchor.surface_text: From the mere fact that the enumeration of the relations is left to the State Government, we cannot say that the Legislature has abdicated its function. It has clearly laid down the policy and on the basis of that policy enumeration of the relations can easily be worked out.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislature laid down policy to ignore benami transfers to relations; enumeration left to executive workable and not abdication; relation has comprehensible local meaning for benami prevention

holdings.text: on the facts placed before us we cannot hold that the Rules are ultra vires the Act

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that on the facts placed before us we cannot hold that the Rules are ultra vires the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No allegation or evidence of increased yield per acre since last settlement or invalid soil classification; Commission can reclassify soils if circumstances changed; Rule 28 follows s.32G principles using last settlement yield prima facie valid

holdings.text: petitioner precluded by Art. 31A from questioning validity of Act or Rules on ground of infringement of fundamental rights under Art. 19, 14 or 31

anchor.surface_text: If so, it follows that the petitioners land is being acquired under a law of acquisition and that the petitioner is precluded, by reason of Art. 31A Of the Constitution, from questioning the validity of the Act or the Rules made thereunder on the ground that his fundamental right under Art. 19, 14 or 31 of the Constitution is infringed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provisions upheld; acquisition under valid law relating to estate; Art. 31A bars challenge to reasonableness or rights violation

precedents.citation: The State of Bihar v. Maharajadhiraja Sir Kameshivar Singh of Darbhanga 1952 S.C.R. 889

anchor.surface_text: the decision of this Court in The State of Bihar v. Maharajadhiraja Sir Kameshivar Singh of Darbhanga 1  concludes the matter against the petitioner on the question raised by him may be noticed. In that case one of the contentions raised was that the Bihar Land Reforms Act, 1950  XXX of 1950  and other Acts were ultra vires the Constitution for want of legislative competency, as law made under Entry 36 of List II of the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution should provide for compensation and as the Acts did not provide for compensation, they were void. This argument was built upon the contention that under Entry 36 of List II of the Seventh Schedule only a law of acquisition could be made that the existence of a public purpose and an obligation to pay compensation are the necessary concomitants of compulsory acquisition of private property, and that, therefore, the term acquisition must be construed as importing, by necessary implication, the two conditions aforesaid. This Court held that the expression acquisition in Entry 36 of List II did not take in the concept of compensation and, therefore, the Acts could not be said to be bad for want of legislative competence.

precedents.case_name: The State of Bihar v. Maharajadhiraja Sir Kameshivar Singh of Darbhanga
precedents.cited_proposition: expression 'acquisition' in Entry 36 of List II of Seventh Schedule does not imply provision for compensation for legislative competence
precedents.cited_holding: the expression acquisition in Entry 36 of List II did not take in the concept of compensation and, therefore, the Acts could not be said to be bad for want of legislative competence

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that on the facts placed before us we cannot hold that the Rules are ultra vires the Act. If so, it follows that the petitioners land is being acquired under a law of acquisition and that the petitioner is precluded, by reason of Art. 31A Of the Constitution, from questioning the validity of the Act or the Rules made thereunder on the ground that his fundamental right under Art. 19, 14 or 31 of the Constitution is infringed.

outcome.relief_summary: Petitioner's claims rejected; provisions held valid; fundamental rights challenge barred by Art. 31A

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that s. 32FF is valid and as the Ian, I acquired is admittedly above the ceiling, the second proviso to art 31A has numberapplication.

We, therefore, hold that on the facts placed before us we cannot hold that the Rules are ultra vires the Act. If so, it follows that the petitioners land is being acquired under a law of acquisition and that the petitioner is precluded, by reason of Art. 31A Of the Constitution, from questioning the validity of the Act or the Rules made thereunder on the ground that his fundamental right under Art. 19, 14 or 31 of the Constitution is infringed.
